data.note: The power market in Costa Rica is regulated under the law 7593 of Aresep. It is regulated and dominated by the vertically integrated Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad (ICE), which is the major generator  of Costa Rica and the sole power purchaser in the country. According to its law, ICE is responsible for national energy demand. The Costa Rican market includes private players, in the form of cooperatives involved with generation and distribution in parts of the country and as independent power producers, selling electricity to ICE.
data.name: The power sector has been unbundled (whether privatized or not) into distinct actors for generation, transmission, distribution and retail

data.note: The Power Market in Costa Rica is regulated under the law 7593 of Aresep. It is regulated and dominated  by the vertically integrated Instituto Costarricense de Eletricidad (ICE), which is the major generator in Costa Rica and the sole power purchaser in the country. According to its law, ICE is responsible for national energy demand.
data.name: There are legally separate private companies at each segment of the power system pre-retail

data.note: The power market in Costa Rica is regulated under the law 7593 of Aresep. It is regulated and dominated by the vertically integrated Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad (ICE), which is the major generator  of Costa Rica and the sole power purchaser in the country. The Costa Rican market includes private players, in the form of cooperatives involved with generation and distribution in parts of the country and as independent power producers, selling electricity to ICE.
data.name: There is an independent transmission system that dispatches according to market dynamics and is not susceptible to state interference

data.note: Electricity subsidies for small consumers were eliminated in 2008.
data.name: Retail electricity prices aren't distorted by subsidies

data.note: Laws 7200 of 1990 and 7508 of 1995 permit limited private sector participation in power generation: in 2014, around 15% of the country's 2.85GW of installed generating capacity were privately owned.The law states that total private sector generation must not exceed 15% of total country generation. At least 35% of private generation companies must be owned by Costa Rican citizens.
data.name: There aren't significant barriers to private sector participation in generation

data.note: There is no competition in the local power market. But there is competition with other power utilities in the region on the Regional Power Market (RPM).
data.name: Consumers can choose retail suppliers or third-party power marketers in the retail power market

data.note: Costa Rica does not have a wholesale power market
data.name: There is a functioning competitive wholesale generation market

data.note: ICE generates 76% of the national production (2014).
data.name: The generation market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players

data.note: Costa Rica's electricity market is governed by ICE, which is the only institution authorized by law to generate. Therefore, all private production must be sold to ICE, according to prices established by Aresep.
data.name: The supply market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players
